title: client/server: introduce DispatchData
body:
The DispatchData mechanism allows global data to be shared by the scope
calling dispatch() with all callbacks that dispatch() invokes, at the
cost of some small runtime checks (basically Any::downcast).

title: Fixed copy-paste error in example
body: Doesn't appear to actually make a difference but for the sake of correctness

body: Fixes #278

title: Add section about the chatrooms in the readme
body: https://github.com/Smithay/wayland-rs/issues/276#issuecomment-537425559

title: Reinstall tarpauling for rust coverage
body: A small try to see if it works better now.

title: commons: use smallvec to store message arguments
body:
Any message with 4 argument or less will have these arguments stored
inline rather than in an heap-allocated vec.

The number 4 was chose because almost all messages have 4 arguments
or less, and some potentially very spammy messages (wl_touch.move)
have exactly 4 arguments. Avoiding allocations in these cases should
generally be a gain.

Moreother, to avoid bloating the size of Message due to this,
String and Array arguments are further boxed, reducing the size
of Argument from 4 usize to 2 usize. These kind of arguments are
generally pretty rare, so the double allocation should overall not
counter the size gain.

Also contains a commit finishing some 2018-ification work.

Closes #268
Closes #249

title: Filter api
body:
Rework of the API of the wayland crates.

Notable changes:

- no more `implement_*` method, instead objects are assigned to `Filter`s, which are some kind of shareable callback. meaning that more than one object can be assigned to a given callback.
- Rather than the dance with `Newproxy`/`NewResource`, proxies and ressources can be assigned and re-assigned to filters. If a message is received for an object not assigned to any filter the result depends on the side:
  - client-side, the message is given to a generic callback that the user has to provide to the `dispatch` methods. The client can thus decide to handle some messages manually rather than via the callbacks.
  - server-side, a message is printed to stderr, and the client is killed with a protocol error message indicating of a server bug.
- client-side, the multithreading handling is done using the new `Main<I>` and `Attached<I>` type (in addition of the `Proxy<I>`/`I` already existing):
  - `Main<I>` is the initial created handle, it is not `Send`, and can be used to send any request and change the proxy assignation to a filter. It cannot exist on an other thread than the one hosting the event queue managing the proxy.
  - `Proxy<I>` is the most shareable handle. It is `Send`, but can only be used to send requests that do *not* create new objects.
  - `Attached<I>` can be created from a `Proxy<I>` by "attaching" the handle to an event queue. It can be used to send any requests, and requests creating new objects will have these new objects managed by the event queue the handle is "attached" to. It is not `Send`.
- Server-side, there is a `Main<I>` as well. Event dispatching & assigning filters can only be done from the thread hosting the `Display`, which is still not threadsafe.
- Client-side: creating a new connection does no longer automatically create a new event queue. You need to create you own, and attach a handle of the `WlDisplay` to it to get your `WlRegistry`.
- User-data is now represented as a `UserData` type, with `set`/`get` methods. It can only be set once and handles thread-safety correctly.
- the `native_lib` feature is renamed to `use_system_lib`, to be more explicit
- client-side: `wayland-cursor` and `wayland-egl` are split into their own crates

TODO:

- [x] polish & uniformize the API
- [x] Update the documentation
- [x] Erase any trace of the event loop abstraction to fully decouple the crate from calloop

title: Add `implement*_user_data_threadsafe()` functions
body:
This follows #269.

I've introduced new implementation functions in `NewProxy` and `NewResource` to be able
to mix thread unsafe implementations with threadsafe user data.

To keep it consistent, it comes in two flavors: `implement` and `implement_closure`. I've also modified the documentation of the non-threadsafe functions, I hope it's ok.

title: Set Proxy::implement_dummy threadsafe
body: Since `|_, _| ()` and `()` are both `Send`, I see no reasons why `Proxy::implement_dummy` shouldn't use `implement_closure_threadsafe` instead of `implement_closure`.

body: This moves the logic of specifying destructor events out of wayland-scanner, as my initial assumption that `wl_callback.done` would be the only ever destructor event turned out to be wrong.

title: Update wlr-protocols

title: Minimize the scope of the native_lib feature
body: This is a refactor of the whole libs, restraining the `native_lib` feature to the `wayland-client` and `wayland-server` crates, the others now being independent of it.

title: client: Display is Clone
body: There was no real reason to prevent client-side `Display` from being clone.

title: client: don't fallback on wayland-0 at connect time
body: The fallback to `wayland-0` if `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` is not set is a legacy practice that should no longer be followed, as it can cause clients to connect to the wrong compositor, and all compositors should set up the environment correctly.

title: travis: run tarpaulin on stable
body:
tarpaulin can now again be compiled on stable, and when run on stable it
does not yet show the multithreading bug.

see https://github.com/xd009642/tarpaulin/issues/190#issuecomment-460054663

title: client: make protocol errors queryable
body:
- Expose `Display::protocol_error()` to retrieve the details of the
  protocol error if any occurred
- Fix the internal logic of the rust implementation so that all pending
  event are still processed even after the server has hung up

title: client: fix a potential race between destruction and queue dispatch
Future proof protocol updates
body:
- Future-proof protocol enums by adding a `#[doc(hidden)] __nonexhaustive` variant. Should be migrated to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/44109 once it is stabilized. This makes updating the protocols a non-breaking change.
- Remove `GlobalManager::instantiate_auto` which was way too error prone, and replace it with `GlobalManager::instanciate_range`. Also improve the docs regarding to interface versioning.
- Actually check that the versions of messages sent and received over the wire are correct wrt to their supported version, and trigger protocol errors if they aren't (as the C lib does).

title: GlobalManager updates
body:
- drop the `Send` bounds,
- fix the warning in `global_filter!()`.

title: client,server: fix races in id recycling
body:
The protocol precisely details how object ids should be used and
recycled, the implementation had some bugs that this corrects.

Notably:

- The server is not expected to send "delete_id" events in response to
  the destruction of server-created objects.
- When a client receives events to an object it just destroyed, the
  handler of this object should **not** be called, and the event
  should be silently dropped instead.
- When an event is silently dropped in the previous case, if it contains
  new_id arguments, the associated ids are still allocated, to match the
  server state.

Fixes #238

title: Unleash Clippy's wrath on travis
body: Clippy is now stable, so lets run it on travis.

title: commons: close fds we dup-ed after sending them
body:
Fixes #235 

@YaLTeR can you confirm this fixes the issue ?

title: Introduce event iterators & sinks
body:
This is the last outstanding point of #228 , this allows downstream users to opt-in to an iterator-based event handling for some of their Wayland objects.

Also introduces an adapter in wayland-client that links an event iterator to an event queue, so that it will block on it if there are no pending events.

title: Refactor to remove RequestsTrait and much of Proxy<_> wrapping
body:
As proposed in https://github.com/Smithay/wayland-rs/issues/228#issuecomment-456297566.

This refactor removes `RequestsTrait`s and moves their methods onto the interface objects themselves. The interface objects contain the corresponding proxies. The end results are:
- It is no longer needed to use `RequestsTrait`s of all objects that requests are sent from, thus lots of boilerplate and renaming (all `RequestsTrait`s clash with each other) is avoided.
- A lot of `Proxy<Interface>` types in the client code are replaced with simply `Interface` which makes the types less complex and easier to understand.

Update of examples and tests is separated into its own commit, check it to see the client code changes.

TODO: update top-level docs on `wayland-client` and the changelog.

title: client+server: make non-send impls the default
body:
The implementation methods are now `.implement()` which allows
non-`Send` implementations and panics if called from the wrong
thread, and `.implement_threadsafe()` which accepts only `Send`
implementations and can be called from any thread.

This is accompanied by removing any `Send` / `Sync` implementations
server-side when the `native_lib` feature is activated, as the
C library actually is never threadsafe (contrarily to the client
one).

title: Trait-based event handling
body:
As discussed in #228 (PoC v2 + `implement_closure()` + `implement_dummy()`).

Implemented client- and server-side.

Additionally I changed the `dynamic_globals` example to use trait-based event handling for `wl_output` as I thought it was a good place where the closure implementation was rather complex with lots of enum cases.

body:
Client ids start at 1 and server ids start at SERVER_ID_LIMIT, not
SERVER_ID_LIMIT+1.

body: Fixes some typos

title: client: introduce Proxy::send_constructor
body:
This new method of `Proxy` sends a message that is expected to create an
object, returning the newly created object. The input message's slot for
the object to create must have previously been filled with a
"placeholder" object (this is checked and failure to do so will panic).

This allows to avoid a race when two threads would conccurently create
objects to send and they end up sent to the server in the wrong order,
causing a protocol error.

fixes #206

title: Migrate to calloop
body:
Parts of this:

- [x] migrate wayland-server to use `calloop` rather than its own event loop
- [x] add `calloop` integration for wayland-client

fixes #185

title: server: implement global filtering capabilities
body:
When creating a global, it is possible to associate a closure to it
that can be used to filter which clients are allowed to see the
existence of this global.

This bumps the minimal version of the wayland libs to 1.13.0.

Fixes #168

title: travis: cache the wayland libs
body:
This avoids rebuilding them every run of the CI, speeding things up.

Fixes #188.

title: Remove the Implementation trait
body:
Its main gain over simple FnMut(..)s was the downcasting abilities, to
check if an object has a given implementation. This advantage is no
longer present now that we have typed user_data since #198.

As such, lets get rid of Implementation, for the sake of simplicity.

To fully retreive all functionnality, it is needed to also introduce an
user-data mechanism on event sources, but this will be done when #185 is
adressed.

Fixes #197.

title: server: rework Client user_data and destructors
body:
Closes #196 

Blocked on https://github.com/Diggsey/lockless/issues/4 or finding an other `AppendList` implementation.

title: Rework Proxy&Resource user_data mechanism
body:
cc #196 

This changes the user data mechanism to be the following:

- the user data of a wayland object is set once and for all at implementation time
- it can be accessed from any handle via a type `user_data<UD>(&self) -> Option<&UD>` method which is a thin wrapper around `Box<Any>::downcast_ref()`
- the user is responsible for integrating interior mutability to the type if they want

In particular, the previous behavior can be reached by using an `AtomicPtr` as the `UD` type, but it makes the default behavior much more safe.

What do you think of this, @Drakulix ?

title: Add more tests & some bugfixes
body: Adding yet again more tests, and fixing little bugs found by them.
